> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Henry Stapp <hstapp@y...> wrote:
> > Hi All,
> >
> > The 'how to test private methods' question (see below) came up on
> the NUnit
> > group, and I thought some TDD gurus here might be able to help out.
> Sorry if
> > this has already been rehashed a hundred times, but I was wrestling
> with
> > this a lot myself, and despite reading the Wiki threads on this, I
> still
> > don't have a good 'pattern' to use...
> >
> [snipped]
>
> >
> > 1) "pollute" the interface by making methods public that should be
> private.
> >
> > 2) Only test the public interface, perhaps giving up detailed
> testing of
> > internal logic.
> >
> > 3) Make more classes... change the private methods into public
> methods of
> > new simple classes.
> >
> > 4) Make the methods 'protected', have your Test class inherit from
> your
> > class under test.
>

In java, protected has not the same meaning as in C++. A protected method is
accessible within the package. The alternative to your point 4) is to make
your methods 'package' and have your Test class in the same package. (IMHO
it is near the first solution, a kind of pollution: private methods are ued
within a class in specific conditions. They should be tested with these
conditions by the public method or the package).
